nodes.title: More Is Different
nodes.author: Charlotte
nodes.body:
Anderson argues that at each level of complexity, entirely new properties appear that cannot be predicted from simpler constituents alone.

> "The ability to reduce everything to simple fundamental laws does not imply the ability to start from those laws and reconstruct the universe."

Key claim: the constructionist hypothesis breaks down when confronted with the twin difficulties of scale and complexity. More is not just quantitatively more — it is qualitatively different.

nodes.title: On Generative Music
nodes.author: Charlotte
nodes.body:
Eno distinguishes between "contemplative" and "generative" art — art that generates itself according to rules vs art that is fixed. Generative systems produce emergence: the composer sets up conditions, not outcomes.

> "I am more interested in making a system that can surprise me than in making a piece that expresses me."

The composer recedes; the system takes over. Resonates with LeWitt's instruction-based conceptual art.

nodes.title: Sentences on Conceptual Art
nodes.author: Charlotte
nodes.body:
> "The idea becomes a machine that makes the art."

LeWitt establishes that the concept precedes execution — the work is the set of instructions, reproducible by anyone. The artist is the architect of a system, not the hand that executes it.

Connection to emergence: the instructions are the micro-level rules; the artwork is the macro-level pattern. The instructions cannot predict the aesthetic outcome.

nodes.title: Weak Emergence
nodes.author: Charlotte
nodes.body:
Bedau distinguishes weak emergence (in principle reducible but computationally intractable) from strong emergence (irreducible in principle). Most emergence observed in natural systems is weak.

The macro-level pattern is derivable from micro-level rules, but only by simulation — there is no shortcut. The simulation *is* the explanation.

Connects to Anderson: the breakdown of reductionism in practice, even if not in principle.
